Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[tests/ci] Add MSBuild test stage to Azure Pipelines" (#3347) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
* Adds a new `mac_msbuild_tests` job to `azure-pipelines.yaml` to run the msbuild tests. This is still a work in progress, we still need to consider commercial and device test execution, as well as better parallelization and Windows execution.

* Appends relevant build log file paths to the test result xml rather than dumping the full log to the test output. It's a bit painful to scroll through diagnostic build output to see which tests failed. This _should_ allow relevant log files to be uploaded directly as attachments to the tests, improving the Azure Pipeline test failure investigation story.

* Adds a new `TestAgainstSystemInstall` property and `TESTINSTALLER` compiler constant to allow for better control of behavior for projects which import `Configuration.props`.

* Removes the dependency on the generated `XABuildPaths.cs` file when building against a system installation. We may want to similarly replace this file in other places with something that doesn't require xaprepare execution.

### Steps to Reproduce

Visual Studio 2019 is able to sign the APK file of your Xamarin Android project, through the "Archive", "Distribute ...", "Ad Hoc" menu options. I checked the signature of the .apk file i got , using the "apksigner.bat" file, that is part of the Android SDK ("C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk\build-tools\29.0.0") with the following command:

**apksigner.bat verify --verbose --print-certs C:\App\temp\com.companyname.App1.apk**

Verifies
Verified using v1 scheme (JAR signing): true
Verified using v2 scheme (APK Signature Scheme v2): false
Number of signers: 1
...

The apk file got from there is not signed with v2 signature scheme.

### Expected Behavior

The apk file got from there should have at least the v2 signature scheme.

### Actual Behavior

You get only v1 signature scheme of the apk file and you can't change that.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "In app projects configured to use AAPT2, builds show incorrect file paths for AAPT2 errors caused by existing library projects built with AAPT that have Android resource elements that are now invalid with AAPT2" (#3344) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: <https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/635696/error-apt0000-inner-element-must-either-be-a-resou.html>

### Steps to reproduce

 1. Build the library project from the test case:

    ```cmd
    msbuild -restore AndroidLibrary1\AndroidLibrary1.csproj
    ```

 2. Build the app project from the test case:

    ```cmd
    msbuild -restore .\AndroidApp1\AndroidApp1.csproj
    ```

Test case: [LibraryResourceAapt2ErrorPath.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3379658/LibraryResourceAapt2ErrorPath.zip)

The library project has `$(AndroidUseAapt2)` set to `false`, while the app project has `$(AndroidUseAapt2)` set to `true`.

### Expected behavior

I'm not sure if [`resource_name_case_map`](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/blob/xamarin-android-9.4.0.34/src/Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks/Tasks/Aapt2.cs#L158) is missing expected information in this scenario or if it's normal that there won't be a mapping for this kind of resource in a prebuilt library. Maybe when the AAPT2 error comes from a prebuilt library project, the best file path to use would be the original location in the *obj\\* directory that AAPT2 prints in the original unparsed error message. So the errors would look something like:

```
C:\Temp\LibraryResourceAaptErrorPath\AndroidApp1\obj\Debug\90\lp\0\jl\res\values\strings.xml(2): error APT0000: <item> inner element must either be a resource reference or empty. [C:\Temp\LibraryResourceAaptErrorPath\AndroidApp1\AndroidApp1.csproj]
C:\Temp\LibraryResourceAaptErrorPath\AndroidApp1\obj\Debug\90\lp\0\jl\res\values\strings.xml : error APT0000: file failed to compile. [C:\Temp\LibraryResourceAaptErrorPath\AndroidApp1\AndroidApp1.csproj]
```

### Actual behavior

The errors show an incorrect file path, making it look like they are coming from the app project, when they are actually coming from the library project:

```
Resources\values\strings.xml(2): error APT0000: <item> inner element must either be a resource reference or empty. [C:\Temp\LibraryResourceAaptErrorPath\AndroidApp1\AndroidApp1.csproj]
Resources\values\strings.xml : error APT0000: file failed to compile. [C:\Temp\LibraryResourceAaptErrorPath\AndroidApp1\AndroidApp1.csproj]
```

### Version information

Xamarin.Android SDK   9.5.0.26 (d16-3/f951e60)

### Log file

[msbuild.binlog.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3379660/msbuild.binlog.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Button CornerRadius doesn't work in explicit style when implicit style exists" (#5046) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description

Applies to Windows UWP only.

When you have
* an implicit style on a Button
* an explicit style on a Button containing a CornerRadius set to anything

Then, the CornerRadius gets set to a value of 5, ignoring the value that is set in the explicit style.

### Steps to Reproduce

Add some code to a page with both an implicit button style (no key), and an explicit button stlye (has a key).

Add a button that references the explicit style.

Sample code:

```
    <ContentPage.Resources>
        <Style TargetType="Button">
            <!--<Setter Property="CornerRadius" Value="0"></Setter>-->
            <Setter Property="BackgroundColor" Value="Blue"></Setter>
            <Setter Property="TextColor" Value="White"></Setter>
        </Style>
        
        <Style x:Key="ButtonStyle" TargetType="Button">
            <Setter Property="CornerRadius" Value="0"></Setter>
            <Setter Property="BackgroundColor" Value="Blue"></Setter>
            <Setter Property="TextColor" Value="Yellow"></Setter>
        </Style>
    </ContentPage.Resources>
    
    <StackLayout>
        <!-- Place new controls here -->
        <Label Text="Welcome to Xamarin.Forms!" 
           HorizontalOptions="Center" />
        
        <Button Text="Hello World" Style="{StaticResource ButtonStyle}"></Button>
    </StackLayout>
```

### Expected Behavior

The CornerRadius from the button's explicit style is used. In the example above, the CornerRadius should be 0.

### Actual Behavior

The CornerRadius from the button's explicit style is not used. In the example above, the CornerRadius is 5.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.4.0.1008975, 3.4.0.1009999, 3.5.0.62956-pre2
- Last known good version: 3.3.0.912540
- IDE: Visual Studio 2018 15.9.4
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - UWP:  16299
- Nuget Packages: Just Xamarin.Forms

### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->
![cornerradius](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6842499/51632317-db880c00-1f03-11e9-9fae-bd01917c8bab.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Enhancement] Xamarin.Forms.TemplateUtilities.GetTemplateChild(string name) should be accessible from exterior namespaces" (#6747) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Closed issue "[Enhancement] Please add custom renderer lifecycle" (#6854) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
## Summary
Please add methods and/or events that we can use to know when a custom renderer has executed. 

## API Changes

A control would have an event, similar to the old `Loaded` or `VisibilityChanged` events so that we know that any associated custom renderers will have had their `OnElementChanged` methods executed.

## Intended Use Case

We have been using an open source control -- [SignaturePad](https://github.com/xamarin/SignaturePad) but found a significant behavior deficiency which we would be unable to work around without forking and "owning" the code, which we would strongly prefer not to do.  The github repo and issues have not been touched in over a year, but there does not seem to be any alternative to that control. The lifecycle event would allow us to use this control as-is.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CollectionView SelectedItem TwoWay Binding  not working" (#5601) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
When I Select an item from the collection the selected item doesn't change
### Steps to Reproduce
Having this XAML
```
<ContentPage>
        <Grid>
            <Grid.ColumnDefinitions>
                <ColumnDefinition />
                <ColumnDefinition Width="auto" />
            </Grid.ColumnDefinitions>
            <CollectionView Grid.Column="0" 
                            SelectionMode="Single"
                            SelectedItem="{Binding SelectedItem, Mode=TwoWay}"
                            ItemsSource="{Binding ObservableCollectionTest}">
                <CollectionView.ItemsLayout>
                    <GridItemsLayout Orientation="Vertical" />
                </CollectionView.ItemsLayout>
                <CollectionView.ItemTemplate>
                    <DataTemplate>
                        <Grid>
                            <Label Text="{Binding}"></Label>
                        </Grid>
                    </DataTemplate>
                </CollectionView.ItemTemplate>
                
            </CollectionView>
            <Label Grid.Column="1"
                   Text="{Binding SelectedItem}" />
        </Grid>
    </ContentPage>
```
With this data in the Model
```
public static string SelectedItemPropertyName() { return nameof(SelectedItem); }
        private string _SelectedItem;
        public string SelectedItem
        {
            get
            {
                return _SelectedItem;
            }
            set
            {
                _SelectedItem = value;
                RaisePropertyChanged();
            }
        }
        public static string ObservableCollectionTestPropertyName() { return nameof(ObservableCollectionTest); }
        private ObservableCollection<string> _ObservableCollectionTest = new ObservableCollection<string>(new List<string>() { "Test1", "test2", "test3" } );
        public ObservableCollection<string> ObservableCollectionTest
        {
            get
            {
                return _ObservableCollectionTest;
            }
            set
            {
                _ObservableCollectionTest = value;
                RaisePropertyChanged();
            }
        }
SelectedItem = ObservableCollectionTest[1];

```

### Expected Behavior
SelectedItem must change its value on each item tap
### Actual Behavior
It doesn't change
### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 4.0.0.232914-pre6 ( not working neither in 4.0 pre-7 neither 4.0 pre-8)
- IDE: Visual Studio Community 2017 version 15.9.9
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply --> 
  - UWP:  Windows 10 version 1803 Build 17134

Closed issue "Any way to suppress specific MTOUCH warnings?" (#6565) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start with a Hello World iOS app
2. add `--enable-repl` to Project Options -> iOS Build -> Additional mtouch arguments
3. Build

### Expected Behavior
* Either there are no warnings, or there is some way to suppress warnings that appear that are related to `--enable-repl`.

### Actual Behavior
* A number of warnings such as the following:
```
MTOUCH: Warning MT0109: The assembly 'mscorlib.dll' was loaded from a different path than the provided path (provided path: /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/Current/lib/mono/Xamarin.iOS/mscorlib.dll, actual path: /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/12.8.0.2/lib/mono/Xamarin.iOS/repl/mscorlib.dll). (MT0109)
```
* There appears to be no way to suppress those warnings.
* I know and expect that the DLLs come from a different path in this case, so these warnings are unhelpful. Is there a way we could not show these MT0109 warnings here? If not, is there a way to suppress a specific MTOUCH warning? I tried adding MT0109 to Project Options -> Compiler -> Ignore warnings, but that did not help.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create any Xamarin.Forms project with VS 2019 community and connect to mac with OS Catalina
2. Set the Build to release and iPhone as device
3. Rebuild the project and could not AOT error comes out

### Expected Behavior
Project should build successfully and ipa file should be generated
### Actual Behavior
throws build error for AOT

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Any way to suppress specific MTOUCH warnings" (#6565) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start with a Hello World iOS app
2. add `--enable-repl` to Project Options -> iOS Build -> Additional mtouch arguments
3. Build

### Expected Behavior
* Either there are no warnings, or there is some way to suppress warnings that appear that are related to `--enable-repl`.

### Actual Behavior
* A number of warnings such as the following:
```
MTOUCH: Warning MT0109: The assembly 'mscorlib.dll' was loaded from a different path than the provided path (provided path: /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/Current/lib/mono/Xamarin.iOS/mscorlib.dll, actual path: /Library/Frameworks/Xamarin.iOS.framework/Versions/12.8.0.2/lib/mono/Xamarin.iOS/repl/mscorlib.dll). (MT0109)
```
* There appears to be no way to suppress those warnings.
* I know and expect that the DLLs come from a different path in this case, so these warnings are unhelpful. Is there a way we could not show these MT0109 warnings here? If not, is there a way to suppress a specific MTOUCH warning? I tried adding MT0109 to Project Options -> Compiler -> Ignore warnings, but that did not help.
